messages: 1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (19:42): with the webworker, there is the worker; and what is the other "thread" ? the page ? the main ? the root ?
f2990be9f224a4f13869d5b11df21db4 (19:43): I believe most people refer to it as the UI thread
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (19:43): "yes".
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (19:44): it's simply the primary thread, and webworker threads are started parallel to it.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (19:44): it's not tied to a specific object or element, it's just "the main thread"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (19:45): browers are fairly free to implement that however they like, as long as the webworked runs parallel to it
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (19:45): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/workers.html#run-a-worker
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (19:48): ok thanks
f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2 (20:07): hey guys, how can I attach an element to the bottom of the page?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:09): that's a bit of a trick question, because there is no "page"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:09): you can add an element so that it becomes the last element in the DOM "document" element, by using document.appendChild(yourelement)
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (20:24): f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2: I'd say that's more of a #css question
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:25): does #css concern itself with using javascript?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:25): (it's pretty much a DOM manipulation question)
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (20:27): q. if i do event.stopPropagation() in a event handler, the other listeners on the same element/event will still receive it, correct?

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:29): "If the capturing EventListener wishes to prevent further processing of the event from occurring it may call the stopProgagation method of the Event interface. This will prevent further dispatch of the event, although additional EventListeners registered at the same hierarchy level will still receive the event."
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:29): so if the browsers conforms to the w3c spec, the answer to your question is yes.
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (20:30): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: any way to prevent it ?
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (20:30): in my case this is for webworker, and so i got all the messages in all the handlers :(
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (20:31): because webwork got no 'hierarchy' like DOM may have
1c32edf178a66ce91df1ac82ee8dd555 (20:36): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: can you give an url on what you pasted ?
f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2 (20:36): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411: thanks, i wasn't sure if I was asking on the right channel actually
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (20:37): f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2: depending on what you actually won't you most likely want position: fixed or position: absolute
f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2 (20:38): alright
f3b20dd0e2e0c07a2098efb3eb80bcf2 (20:38): I just wanted to know if there was another technique than position absolute
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:49): jetienne, http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-2-Events/events.html#Events-flow-capture

0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (21:10): I think it doesn't matter until someone writes a nasty enough virus using IE6 as an attack vector and nukes China out from the internet :I
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (21:10): so that would be... the day it EOLs

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (21:11): the lack of webgl is a bit sad, but I'm not going to shoot down microsoft for finally getting back to making a browser that at least supports the internet as it was used when it came out

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (21:15): a) you have rights on your computer - you don't need chrome frame

1353d9b683d6d7b4281d762ca742bdb9 (21:16): c)the ms admins wont even know
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (21:16): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: actually I have talked for one enterprise where they are happy about Google Frame

d9d3cb22ec4f4fa022a95c197ca6871b (21:16): if it's user land software it's not circumventing security polices

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (21:16): but if you work for a dinosaur, it's a potential pink slip
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (21:16): and they don't need to support IE in internal applications any longer
